{"title": ["JavaScript"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/JavaScript_code.png/300px-JavaScript_code.png"], "desc": " implementation as an "}

This sparked a renaissance period of JavaScript, spearheaded by open-source libraries and the communities that formed around them. Many new libraries were created, including "}

Browser authors minimize this risk using two restrictions. First, scripts run in a "}
{"title": ["JavaScript"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/JavaScript_code.png/300px-JavaScript_code.png"], "desc": " in which they can only perform Web-related actions, not general-purpose programming tasks like creating files. Second, scripts are constrained by the "}
{"title": ["JavaScript"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/JavaScript_code.png/300px-JavaScript_code.png"], "desc": ": scripts from one website do not have access to information such as usernames, passwords, or cookies sent to another site. Most JavaScript-related security bugs are breaches of either the same origin policy or the sandbox.\n"}
{"title": ["JavaScript"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/JavaScript_code.png/300px-JavaScript_code.png"], "desc": "There are subsets of general JavaScript\u2014ADsafe, Secure ECMAScript (SES)\u2014that provide greater levels of security, especially on code created by third parties (such as advertisements)."}
{"title": ["JavaScript"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/JavaScript_code.png/300px-JavaScript_code.png"], "desc": " Closure Toolkit is another project for safe embedding and isolation of third-party JavaScript and HTML."}

{"title": ["JavaScript"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/JavaScript_code.png/300px-JavaScript_code.png"], "desc": "A common JavaScript-related security problem is "}
{"title": ["JavaScript"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/JavaScript_code.png/300px-JavaScript_code.png"], "desc": " (XSS), a violation of the "}
{"title": ["JavaScript"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/JavaScript_code.png/300px-JavaScript_code.png"], "desc": ". XSS vulnerabilities occur when an attacker can cause a target Website, such as an online banking website, to include a malicious script in the webpage presented to a victim. The script in this example can then access the banking application with the privileges of the victim, potentially disclosing secret information or transferring money without the victim's authorization. One important solution to XSS vulnerabilities is "}
{"title": ["JavaScript"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/JavaScript_code.png/300px-JavaScript_code.png"], "desc": ".\n"}
{"title": ["JavaScript"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/JavaScript_code.png/300px-JavaScript_code.png"], "desc": "Some browsers include partial protection against "}
{"title": ["JavaScript"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/JavaScript_code.png/300px-JavaScript_code.png"], "desc": " XSS attacks, in which the attacker provides a URL including malicious script. However, even users of those browsers are vulnerable to other XSS attacks, such as those where the malicious code is stored in a database. Only correct design of Web applications on the server-side can fully prevent XSS.\n"}
{"title": ["JavaScript"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/JavaScript_code.png/300px-JavaScript_code.png"], "desc": "XSS vulnerabilities can also occur because of implementation mistakes by browser authors."}
{"title": ["JavaScript"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/JavaScript_code.png/300px-JavaScript_code.png"], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["JavaScript"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/JavaScript_code.png/300px-JavaScript_code.png"], "desc": "Another cross-site vulnerability is "}
{"title": ["JavaScript"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/JavaScript_code.png/300px-JavaScript_code.png"], "desc": " (CSRF). In CSRF, code on an attacker's site tricks the victim's browser into taking actions the user did not intend at a target site (like transferring money at a bank). When target sites rely solely on cookies for request authentication, requests originating from code on the attacker's site can carry the same valid login credentials of the initiating user. In general, the solution to CSRF is to require an authentication value in a hidden form field, and not only in the cookies, to authenticate any request that might have lasting effects. Checking the HTTP Referrer header can also help.\n"}
{"title": ["JavaScript"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/JavaScript_code.png/300px-JavaScript_code.png"], "desc": "\"JavaScript hijacking\" is a type of CSRF attack in which a "}
{"title": ["JavaScript"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/JavaScript_code.png/300px-JavaScript_code.png"], "desc": " tag on an attacker's site exploits a page on the victim's site that returns private information such as "}
{"title": ["JavaScript"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/JavaScript_code.png/300px-JavaScript_code.png"], "desc": " or JavaScript. Possible solutions include:\n"}
{"title": ["JavaScript"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/JavaScript_code.png/300px-JavaScript_code.png"], "desc": "Developers of client-server applications must recognize that untrusted clients may be under the control of attackers. The author of an application should not assume that their JavaScript code will run as intended (or at all) because any secret embedded in the code could be extracted by a determined adversary. Some implications are:\n"}
{"title": ["JavaScript"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/JavaScript_code.png/300px-JavaScript_code.png"], "desc": "Package management systems such as "}
{"title": ["JavaScript"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/JavaScript_code.png/300px-JavaScript_code.png"], "desc": " and Bower are popular with JavaScript developers. Such systems allow a developer to easily manage their program's dependencies upon other developers' program libraries. Developers trust that the maintainers of the libraries will keep them secure and up to date, but that is not always the case. A vulnerability has emerged because of this blind trust. Relied-upon libraries can have new releases that cause bugs or vulnerabilities to appear in all programs that rely upon the libraries. Inversely, a library can go unpatched with known vulnerabilities out in the wild. In a study done looking over a sample of 133,000 websites, researchers found 37% of the websites included a library with at least one known vulnerability."}
{"title": ["JavaScript"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/JavaScript_code.png/300px-JavaScript_code.png"], "desc": " \"The median lag between the oldest library version used on each website and the newest available version of that library is 1,177 days in ALEXA, and development of some libraries still in active use ceased years ago.\""}
{"title": ["JavaScript"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/JavaScript_code.png/300px-JavaScript_code.png"], "desc": " Another possibility is that the maintainer of a library may remove the library entirely. This occurred in March 2016 when Azer Ko\u00e7ulu removed his repository from npm. This caused tens of thousands of programs and websites depending upon his libraries to break."}

{"title": ["PHP"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/PHP-logo.svg/200px-PHP-logo.svg.png"], "desc": "Beginning on 28 June 2011, the PHP Development Team implemented a timeline for the release of new versions of PHP."}
{"title": ["PHP"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/PHP-logo.svg/200px-PHP-logo.svg.png"], "desc": " Under this system, at least one release should occur every month. Once per year, a minor release should occur which may include new features. Every minor release should at least be supported for two years with security and bug fixes, followed by at least one year of only security fixes, for a total of a three-year release process for every minor release. No new features, unless small and self-contained, are to be introduced into a minor release during the three-year release process.\n"}

{"title": ["Node.js"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Node.js_logo.svg/220px-Node.js_logo.svg.png"], "desc": " (LTS), which gives that version 12 months of active support from the date it is designated LTS. After these 12 months expire, an LTS release receives an additional 18 months of maintenance support. An active version receives non-breaking backports of changes a few weeks after they land in the current release. A maintenance release receives only critical fixes and documentation updates."}

{"title": ["Node.js"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Node.js_logo.svg/220px-Node.js_logo.svg.png"], "desc": "A thread pool handles the execution of parallel tasks in Node.js. The main thread function call posts tasks to the shared task queue, which threads in the thread pool pull and execute. Inherently non-blocking system functions such as networking translate to kernel-side non-blocking sockets, while inherently blocking system functions such as file I/O run in a blocking way on their own threads. When a thread in the thread pool completes a task, it informs the main thread of this, which in turn, wakes up and executes the registered callback.\n"}
{"title": ["Node.js"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Node.js_logo.svg/220px-Node.js_logo.svg.png"], "desc": "A downside of this single-threaded approach is that Node.js does not allow "}

To address the issue, third parties have introduced open-sourced \u0421/\u0421++ wrappers on top of the API that partially alleviate the problem. They simplify interfaces, but as a side effect they may also introduce complexity which maintainers have to deal with. Even though the core functionality of Node.js resides in a JavaScript built-in library, modules written in C++ can be used to enhance capabilities and to improve performance of applications.\n"}

{"title": ["React (software)"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/React_Logo_SVG.svg/100px-React_Logo_SVG.svg.png"], "desc": "This unconventional clause caused some controversy and debate in the React user community, because it could be interpreted to empower Facebook to revoke the license in many scenarios, for example, if Facebook sues the licensee prompting them to take \"other action\" by publishing the action on a blog or elsewhere. Many expressed concerns that Facebook could unfairly exploit the termination clause or that integrating React into a product might complicate a startup company's future acquisition."}

{"title": ["React (software)"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/React_Logo_SVG.svg/100px-React_Logo_SVG.svg.png"], "desc": "JavaScript-based web application frameworks, such as React, provide extensive capabilities but come with associated trade-offs. These frameworks often extend or enhance features available through native web technologies, such as routing, component-based development, and state management. While native web standards, including Web Components, modern JavaScript APIs like Fetch and ES Modules, and browser capabilities like Shadow DOM, have advanced significantly, frameworks remain widely used for their ability to enhance developer productivity, offer structured patterns for large-scale applications, simplify handling edge cases, and provide tools for performance optimization. "}
{"title": ["React (software)"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/React_Logo_SVG.svg/100px-React_Logo_SVG.svg.png"], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["React (software)"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/React_Logo_SVG.svg/100px-React_Logo_SVG.svg.png"], "desc": "Frameworks can introduce abstraction layers that may contribute to performance overhead, larger bundle sizes, and increased complexity. Modern frameworks, such as React 18, address these challenges with features like concurrent rendering, tree-shaking, and selective hydration. While these advancements improve rendering efficiency and resource management, their benefits depend on the specific application and implementation context. Lightweight frameworks, such as Svelte and Preact, take different architectural approaches, with Svelte eliminating the virtual DOM entirely in favor of compiling components to efficient JavaScript code, and Preact offering a minimal, compatible alternative to React. Framework choice depends on an application\u2019s requirements, including the team\u2019s expertise, performance goals, and development priorities. "}
{"title": ["React (software)"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/React_Logo_SVG.svg/100px-React_Logo_SVG.svg.png"], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["React (software)"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/React_Logo_SVG.svg/100px-React_Logo_SVG.svg.png"], "desc": "A newer category of web frameworks, including enhance.dev, Astro, and Fresh, leverages native web standards while minimizing abstractions and development tooling. "}
{"title": ["React (software)"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/React_Logo_SVG.svg/100px-React_Logo_SVG.svg.png"], "desc": " These solutions emphasize "}
{"title": ["React (software)"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/React_Logo_SVG.svg/100px-React_Logo_SVG.svg.png"], "desc": ", "}
{"title": ["React (software)"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/React_Logo_SVG.svg/100px-React_Logo_SVG.svg.png"], "desc": ", and optimizing performance. Astro renders static HTML by default while hydrating only interactive parts. Fresh focuses on server-side rendering with zero runtime overhead. Enhance.dev prioritizes progressive enhancement patterns using Web Components. While these tools reduce reliance on client-side JavaScript by shifting logic to build-time or server-side execution, they still use JavaScript where necessary for interactivity. This approach makes them particularly suitable for performance-critical and content-focused applications. "}

{"title": ["Vue.js"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Vue.js_Logo_2.svg/170px-Vue.js_Logo_2.svg.png"], "desc": "A traditional disadvantage of "}
{"title": ["Vue.js"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Vue.js_Logo_2.svg/170px-Vue.js_Logo_2.svg.png"], "desc": " (SPAs) is the inability to share links to the exact \"sub\" page within a specific web page. Because SPAs serve their users only one URL-based response from the server (it typically serves index.html or index.vue),  bookmarking certain screens or sharing links to specific sections is normally difficult if not impossible. To solve this problem, many client-side routers delimit their dynamic URLs with a \""}
{"title": ["Vue.js"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Vue.js_Logo_2.svg/170px-Vue.js_Logo_2.svg.png"], "desc": "\" (#!), e.g. "}
{"title": ["Vue.js"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Vue.js_Logo_2.svg/170px-Vue.js_Logo_2.svg.png"], "desc": ". However, with HTML5 most modern browsers support routing without hashbangs.\n"}
{"title": ["Vue.js"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Vue.js_Logo_2.svg/170px-Vue.js_Logo_2.svg.png"], "desc": "Vue provides an interface to change what is displayed on the page based on the current URL path \u2013 regardless of how it was changed (whether by emailed link, refresh, or in-page links). Additionally, using a front-end router allows for the intentional transition of the browser path when certain browser events (i.e. clicks) occur on buttons or links. Vue itself doesn't come with front-end hashed routing. But the open-source \"vue-router\" package provides an API to update the application's URL, supports the back button (navigating history), and email password resets or email verification links with authentication URL parameters. It supports mapping nested routes to nested components and offers fine-grained transition control. With Vue, developers are already composing applications with small building blocks building larger components. With vue-router added to the mix, components must merely be mapped to the routes they belong to, and parent/root routes must indicate where children should render."}
{"title": ["Vue.js"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Vue.js_Logo_2.svg/170px-Vue.js_Logo_2.svg.png"], "desc": "\n"}

These frameworks often extend or enhance features available through native web technologies, such as routing, component-based development, and state management. While native web standards, including Web Components, modern JavaScript APIs like Fetch and ES Modules, and browser capabilities like Shadow DOM, have advanced significantly, frameworks remain widely used for their ability to enhance developer productivity, offer structured patterns for large-scale applications, simplify handling edge cases, and provide tools for performance optimization. "}
{"title": ["Vue.js"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Vue.js_Logo_2.svg/170px-Vue.js_Logo_2.svg.png"], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["Vue.js"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Vue.js_Logo_2.svg/170px-Vue.js_Logo_2.svg.png"], "desc": "Frameworks can introduce abstraction layers that may contribute to performance overhead, larger bundle sizes, and increased complexity. Modern frameworks, such as Vue 3, address these challenges with features like concurrent rendering, tree-shaking, and selective hydration. While these advancements improve rendering efficiency and resource management, their benefits depend on the specific application and implementation context. Lightweight frameworks, such as Svelte and Preact, take different architectural approaches, with Svelte eliminating the virtual DOM entirely in favor of compiling components to efficient JavaScript code, and Preact offering a minimal, compatible alternative to React. Framework choice depends on an application\u2019s requirements, including the team\u2019s expertise, performance goals, and development priorities. "}

{"title": ["Vue.js"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Vue.js_Logo_2.svg/170px-Vue.js_Logo_2.svg.png"], "desc": "A newer category of web frameworks, including enhance.dev, Astro, and Fresh, leverages native web standards while minimizing abstractions and development tooling. "}
{"title": ["Vue.js"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Vue.js_Logo_2.svg/170px-Vue.js_Logo_2.svg.png"], "desc": " These solutions emphasize "}
{"title": ["Vue.js"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Vue.js_Logo_2.svg/170px-Vue.js_Logo_2.svg.png"], "desc": ", "}
{"title": ["Vue.js"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Vue.js_Logo_2.svg/170px-Vue.js_Logo_2.svg.png"], "desc": ", and optimizing performance. Astro renders static HTML by default while hydrating only interactive parts. Fresh focuses on server-side rendering with zero runtime overhead. Enhance.dev prioritizes progressive enhancement patterns using Web Components. While these tools reduce reliance on client-side JavaScript by shifting logic to build-time or server-side execution, they still use JavaScript where necessary for interactivity. This approach makes them particularly suitable for performance-critical and content-focused applications. "}

{"title": ["Go (programming language)"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Go_Logo_Blue.svg/230px-Go_Logo_Blue.svg.png"], "desc": "-style concurrent languages like Erlang, where messages are addressed directly to actors (corresponding to goroutines). In the actor model, channels are themselves actors, therefore addressing a channel just means to address an actor. The actor style can be simulated in Go by maintaining a one-to-one correspondence between goroutines and channels, but the language allows multiple goroutines to share a channel or a single goroutine to send and receive on multiple channels."}
{"title": ["Go (programming language)"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Go_Logo_Blue.svg/230px-Go_Logo_Blue.svg.png"], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["Go (programming language)"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Go_Logo_Blue.svg/230px-Go_Logo_Blue.svg.png"], "desc": "From these tools one can build concurrent constructs like "}
{"title": ["Go (programming language)"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Go_Logo_Blue.svg/230px-Go_Logo_Blue.svg.png"], "desc": ", pipelines (in which, say, a file is decompressed and parsed as it downloads), background calls with timeout, \"fan-out\" parallel calls to a set of services, and others."}
{"title": ["Go (programming language)"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Go_Logo_Blue.svg/230px-Go_Logo_Blue.svg.png"], "desc": " Channels have also found uses further from the usual notion of interprocess communication, like serving as a concurrency-safe list of recycled buffers,"}

{"title": ["Go (programming language)"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Go_Logo_Blue.svg/230px-Go_Logo_Blue.svg.png"], "desc": " While the communicating-processes model is favored in Go, it is not the only one: all goroutines in a program share a single address space. This means that mutable objects and pointers can be shared between goroutines; see "}

{"title": ["Go (programming language)"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Go_Logo_Blue.svg/230px-Go_Logo_Blue.svg.png"], "desc": ", "}
{"title": ["Go (programming language)"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Go_Logo_Blue.svg/230px-Go_Logo_Blue.svg.png"], "desc": " and "}
{"title": ["Go (programming language)"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Go_Logo_Blue.svg/230px-Go_Logo_Blue.svg.png"], "desc": ". The study found that the non-expert tended to write "}
{"title": ["Go (programming language)"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Go_Logo_Blue.svg/230px-Go_Logo_Blue.svg.png"], "desc": " algorithms with one "}
{"title": ["Go (programming language)"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Go_Logo_Blue.svg/230px-Go_Logo_Blue.svg.png"], "desc": " statement per recursion, while the expert wrote distribute-work-synchronize programs using one goroutine per processor core. The expert's programs were usually faster, but also longer."}
{"title": ["Go (programming language)"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Go_Logo_Blue.svg/230px-Go_Logo_Blue.svg.png"], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["Go (programming language)"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Go_Logo_Blue.svg/230px-Go_Logo_Blue.svg.png"], "desc": "Go's approach to concurrency can be summarized as \"don't communicate by sharing memory; share memory by communicating\"."}
{"title": ["Go (programming language)"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Go_Logo_Blue.svg/230px-Go_Logo_Blue.svg.png"], "desc": " There are no restrictions on how goroutines access shared data, making "}
{"title": ["Go (programming language)"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Go_Logo_Blue.svg/230px-Go_Logo_Blue.svg.png"], "desc": " possible. Specifically, unless a program explicitly synchronizes via channels or other means, writes from one goroutine might be partly, entirely, or not at all visible to another, often with no guarantees about ordering of writes."}
{"title": ["Go (programming language)"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Go_Logo_Blue.svg/230px-Go_Logo_Blue.svg.png"], "desc": " Furthermore, Go's "}
{"title": ["Go (programming language)"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Go_Logo_Blue.svg/230px-Go_Logo_Blue.svg.png"], "desc": " like interface values, slice headers, hash tables, and string headers are not immune to data races, so type and memory safety can be violated in multithreaded programs that modify shared instances of those types without synchronization."}
{"title": ["Go (programming language)"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Go_Logo_Blue.svg/230px-Go_Logo_Blue.svg.png"], "desc": " Instead of language support, safe concurrent programming thus relies on conventions; for example, Chisnall recommends an idiom called \"aliases "}
{"title": ["Go (programming language)"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Go_Logo_Blue.svg/230px-Go_Logo_Blue.svg.png"], "desc": " mutable\", meaning that passing a mutable value (or pointer) over a channel signals a transfer of ownership over the value to its receiver."}

{"title": ["C++"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg/125px-ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg.png"], "desc": "). Dynamic initialization involves all object initialization done via a constructor or function call (unless the function is marked with "}
{"title": ["C++"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg/125px-ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg.png"], "desc": ", in C++11). The dynamic initialization order is defined as the order of declaration within the compilation unit (i.e. the same file). No guarantees are provided about the order of initialization between compilation units.\n"}

Array members are initialized from 0 to the last member of the array in order. Member variables are destroyed when the parent object is destroyed in the reverse order of creation. i.e. If the parent is an \"automatic object\" then it will be destroyed when it goes out of scope which triggers the destruction of all its members.\n"}

{"title": ["C++"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg/125px-ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg.png"], "desc": ", and code optimization, but this power implies a cost. Template use may increase "}
{"title": ["C++"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg/125px-ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg.png"], "desc": " size, because each template instantiation produces a copy of the template code: one for each set of template arguments, however, this is the same or smaller amount of code that would be generated if the code were written by hand."}

{"title": ["C++"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg/125px-ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg.png"], "desc": "Templates are different from "}
{"title": ["C++"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg/125px-ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg.png"], "desc": ": while both of these compile-time language features enable conditional compilation, templates are not restricted to lexical substitution. Templates are aware of the semantics and type system of their companion language, as well as all compile-time type definitions, and can perform high-level operations including programmatic flow control based on evaluation of strictly type-checked parameters. Macros are capable of conditional control over compilation based on predetermined criteria, but cannot instantiate new types, recurse, or perform type evaluation and in effect are limited to pre-compilation text-substitution and text-inclusion/exclusion. In other words, macros can control compilation flow based on pre-defined symbols but cannot, unlike templates, independently instantiate new symbols. Templates are a tool for static "}
{"title": ["C++"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg/125px-ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg.png"], "desc": " (see below) and "}

{"title": ["C++"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg/125px-ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg.png"], "desc": ", meaning that any computation expressible by a computer program can be computed, in some form, by a "}
{"title": ["C++"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg/125px-ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg.png"], "desc": " before runtime.\n"}
{"title": ["C++"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg/125px-ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg.png"], "desc": "In summary, a template is a compile-time parameterized function or class written without knowledge of the specific arguments used to instantiate it. After instantiation, the resulting code is equivalent to code written specifically for the passed arguments. In this manner, templates provide a way to decouple generic, broadly applicable aspects of functions and classes (encoded in templates) from specific aspects (encoded in template parameters) without sacrificing performance due to abstraction.\n"}
{"title": ["C++"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg/125px-ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg.png"], "desc": "C++ introduces "}

{"title": ["C++"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg/125px-ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg.png"], "desc": " (RAII) concept.\n"}
{"title": ["C++"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg/125px-ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg.png"], "desc": " is the hiding of information to ensure that data structures and operators are used as intended and to make the usage model more obvious to the developer. C++ provides the ability to define classes and functions as its primary encapsulation mechanisms. Within a class, members can be declared as either public, protected, or private to explicitly enforce encapsulation. A public member of the class is accessible to any function. A private member is accessible only to functions that are members of that class and to functions and classes explicitly granted access permission by the class (\"friends\"). A protected member is accessible to members of classes that inherit from the class in addition to the class itself and any friends.\n"}
{"title": ["C++"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg/125px-ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg.png"], "desc": "The object-oriented principle ensures the encapsulation of all and only the functions that access the internal representation of a type. C++ supports this principle via member functions and friend functions, but it does not enforce it. Programmers can declare parts or all of the representation of a type to be public, and they are allowed to make public entities not part of the representation of a type. Therefore, C++ supports not just object-oriented programming, but other decomposition paradigms such as "}
{"title": ["C++"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg/125px-ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg.png"], "desc": ".\n"}
{"title": ["C++"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg/125px-ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg.png"], "desc": "It is generally considered good practice to make all "}

This can hide the details of data implementation, allowing the designer to later fundamentally change the implementation without changing the interface in any way."}

This access specifier determines whether unrelated and derived classes can access the inherited public and protected members of the base class. Only public inheritance corresponds to what is usually meant by \"inheritance\". The other two forms are much less frequently used. If the access specifier is omitted, a \"class\" inherits privately, while a \"struct\" inherits publicly. Base classes may be declared as virtual; this is called "}

{"title": ["C++"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg/125px-ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg.png"], "desc": "When declaring a function, a programmer can specify for one or more parameters a "}

Doing so allows the parameters with defaults to optionally be omitted when the function is called, in which case the default arguments will be used. When a function is called with fewer arguments than there are declared parameters, explicit arguments are matched to parameters in left-to-right order, with any unmatched parameters at the end of the parameter list being assigned their default arguments. In many cases, specifying default arguments in a single function declaration is preferable to providing overloaded function definitions with different numbers of parameters.\n"}

This allows arrays and other kinds of containers to hold pointers to objects of differing types (references cannot be directly held in containers). An inexact rule based on practical experience states that if any function in the class is virtual, the destructor should be as well. As the type of an object at its creation is known at compile time, constructors, and by extension copy constructors, cannot be virtual. Objects cannot be created from an abstract class; they can only be derived from. Any derived class inherits the virtual function as pure and must provide a non-pure definition of it (and all other pure virtual functions) before objects of the derived class can be created. A program that attempts to create an object of a class with a pure virtual member function or inherited pure virtual member function is ill-formed.\n"}

{"title": ["C++"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg/125px-ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg.png"], "desc": " keyword; these exceptions are handled in the usual way. In some cases, exceptions cannot be used due to technical reasons. One such example is a critical component of an embedded system, where every operation must be guaranteed to complete within a specified amount of time. This cannot be determined with exceptions as no tools exist to determine the maximum time required for an exception to be handled."}

{"title": ["C++"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg/125px-ISO_C%2B%2B_Logo.svg.png"], "desc": ", who experimented with generic algorithms and containers for many years. When he started with C++, he finally found a language where it was possible to create generic algorithms (e.g., STL sort) that perform even better than, for example, the C standard library qsort, thanks to C++ features like using inlining and compile-time binding instead of function pointers. The standard does not refer to it as \"STL\", as it is merely a part of the standard library, but the term is still widely used to distinguish it from the rest of the standard library (input/output streams, internationalization, diagnostics, the C library subset, etc.)."}

{"title": ["Java"], "image": [], "desc": ", beginning 1.51 to 0.93 million years ago at the Sangiran site, continuing 540 to 430 thousand years ago at the Trinil site, and finally 117 to 108 thousand years ago at Ngandong."}

{"title": ["Java"], "image": [], "desc": " (a species currently recognisable only by their genetic signature) across Southeast Asia, whereupon they interbred with immigrating modern humans 45.7 and 29.8 thousand years ago."}

This site is quite far from the north coast of Java Island, and it is not always easy to determine the position of the coastline in prehistoric times because of significant geographical changes."}
{"title": ["Java"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["Java"], "image": [], "desc": "The southern coastline and estuary of the Bengawan Solo River at that time may have been different from what it is today, due to geological factors such as sedimentation, erosion, and changes in sea level over time. Currently, the estuary of the Bengawan Solo is in the Java Sea, but in prehistoric times, the river flow and estuary location may have changed. Geological and paleogeographic studies are often used to understand these changes.\n"}
{"title": ["Java"], "image": [], "desc": "The island's exceptional fertility and rainfall allowed the development of wet-field rice cultivation, which required sophisticated levels of cooperation between villages. Out of these village alliances, small kingdoms developed. The chain of volcanic mountains and associated highlands running the length of Java kept its interior regions and peoples separate and relatively isolated."}
{"title": ["Java"], "image": [], "desc": " Before the advent of Islamic states and European colonialism, the rivers provided the main means of communication, although Java's many rivers are mostly short. Only the "}
{"title": ["Java"], "image": [], "desc": " and Solo river could provide long-distance communication and this way their valleys supported the centers of major kingdoms. A system of roads, permanent bridges, and toll gates is thought to have been established in Java by at least the mid-17th century. Local powers could disrupt the routes as could the wet season and road use was highly dependent on constant maintenance. Consequently, communication between Java's population was difficult."}

{"title": ["Java"], "image": [], "desc": "Java has been traditionally dominated by an elite class, while the people in the lower classes were often involved in agriculture and fishing. The elite class in Java has evolved over the course of history, as cultural wave after cultural wave immigrated to the island. There is evidence that South Asian emigres were among this elite, as well as Arabian and Persian immigrants during the Islamic eras. More recently, Chinese immigrants have also become part of the economic elite of Java. Although politically the Chinese generally remain sidelined, there are notable exceptions, such as the former governor of Jakarta, "}

{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " aspects of software development. Labels, milestones, responsibility assignment, and a search engine are available for issue tracking. For version control, Git (and, by extension, GitHub) allows "}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " to propose changes to the source code. Users who can review the proposed changes can see a diff between the requested changes and approve them. In Git terminology, this action is called \"committing\" and one instance of it is a \"commit.\" A history of all commits is kept and can be viewed at a later time.\n"}

{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " pipelines for testing, releasing and deploying software without the use of third-party websites/platforms.\n"}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "GitHub also operates a "}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "-style site called "}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": ", which is for "}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": ", as opposed to GitHub proper, which is usually used for larger projects."}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " Tom Preston-Werner d\u00e9buted the feature at a Ruby conference in 2008."}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "Gist builds on the traditional simple concept of a "}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " by adding version control for code snippets, easy forking, and "}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " for private pastes. Because each \"gist\" is its own Git repository, multiple code snippets can be contained in a single page, and they can be pushed and pulled using Git."}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "Unregistered users could upload Gists until March 19, 2018, when uploading Gists was restricted to logged-in users, reportedly to mitigate "}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " on the page of recent Gists."}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "Gists' "}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " use hexadecimal IDs, and edits to Gists are recorded in a "}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": ", which can show the text difference of thirty revisions per page with an option between a \"split\" and \"unified\" view. Like repositories, Gists can be forked, \"starred\", i.e., publicly bookmarked, and commented on. The count of revisions, stars, and forks is indicated on the gist page."}

{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "In 2016, GitHub announced the launch of the GitHub Campus Experts program"}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " to train and encourage students to grow technology communities at their universities. The Campus Experts program is open to university students 18 years and older worldwide."}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " GitHub Campus Experts are one of the primary ways that GitHub funds student-oriented events and communities, Campus Experts are given access to training, funding, and additional resources to run events and grow their communities. To become a Campus Expert, applicants must complete an online training course with multiple modules to develop community leadership skills.\n"}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "GitHub also provides some "}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " (SaaS) integrations for adding extra features to projects. Those services include:\n"}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "GitHub Sponsors allows users to make monthly money donations to projects hosted on GitHub."}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " The public beta was announced on May 23, 2019, and the project accepts waitlist registrations. "}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " said that GitHub Sponsors \"works exactly like "}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "\" because \"developers can offer various funding tiers that come with different perks, and they'll receive recurring payments from supporters who want to access them and encourage their work\" except with \"zero fees to use the program.\" Furthermore, GitHub offers incentives for early adopters during the first year: it pledges to cover payment processing costs and match sponsorship payments up to $5,000 per developer. Furthermore, users can still use similar services like Patreon and Open Collective and link to their websites."}

{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " pulse laser, i.e. one that pulses a "}

{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "In March 2014, GitHub programmer Julie Ann Horvath alleged that founder and CEO Tom Preston-Werner and his wife, Theresa, engaged in a pattern of "}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " against her that led to her leaving the company."}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " In April 2014, GitHub released a statement denying Horvath's allegations."}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " However, following an internal investigation, GitHub confirmed the claims. GitHub's CEO Chris Wanstrath wrote on the company blog, \"The investigation found Tom Preston-Werner in his capacity as GitHub's CEO acted inappropriately, including confrontational conduct, disregard of workplace complaints, insensitivity to the impact of his spouse's presence in the workplace, and failure to enforce an agreement that his spouse should not work in the office.\""}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " Preston-Werner subsequently resigned from the company."}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " The firm then announced it would implement new initiatives and trainings \"to make sure employee concerns and conflicts are taken seriously and dealt with appropriately.\""}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "On July 25, 2019, a developer based in Iran wrote on "}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " that GitHub had blocked his private repositories and prohibited access to GitHub pages."}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " Soon after, GitHub confirmed that it was now blocking developers in "}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": ", "}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": ", "}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": ", "}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": ", and "}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " from accessing private repositories."}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " However, GitHub reopened access to GitHub Pages days later, for public repositories regardless of location. It was also revealed that using GitHub while visiting sanctioned countries could result in similar actions occurring on a user's account. GitHub responded to complaints and the media through a spokesperson, saying:\n"}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "Developers who feel that they should not have restrictions can appeal for the removal of said restrictions, including those who only travel to, and do not reside in, those countries. GitHub has forbidden the use of "}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " and "}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " to access the site from sanctioned countries, as purchase history and IP addresses are how they flag users, among other sources."}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "On December 4, 2014, Russia blacklisted GitHub.com because GitHub initially refused to take down user-posted suicide manuals."}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " After a day, Russia withdrew its block,"}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " and GitHub began blocking specific content and pages in Russia."}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " On December 31, 2014, India blocked GitHub.com along with 31 other websites over pro-"}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " content posted by users;"}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " the block was lifted three days later."}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " On October 8, 2016, Turkey blocked GitHub to prevent email leakage of a hacked account belonging to the country's energy minister."}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "On March 26, 2015, a large-scale "}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " attack was launched against GitHub.com that lasted for just under five days."}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " The attack, which appeared to originate from China, primarily targeted GitHub-hosted user content describing methods of "}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "."}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "On April 19, 2020, Chinese police detained Chen Mei and Cai Wei (volunteers for Terminus 2049, a project hosted on GitHub), and accused them of \"picking quarrels and provoking trouble.\" Cai and Chen archived news articles, interviews, and other materials published on Chinese media outlets and social media platforms that have been removed by censors in China."}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "GitHub has a $200,000 contract with "}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " (ICE) for the use of their on-site product GitHub Enterprise Server. This contract was renewed in 2019, despite internal opposition from many GitHub employees. In an email sent to employees, later posted to the GitHub blog on October 9, 2019, CEO "}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " stated, \"The revenue from the purchase is less than $200,000 and not financially material for our company.\" He announced that GitHub had pledged to donate $500,000 to \"nonprofit groups supporting immigrant communities targeted by "}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": ".\""}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " In response, at least 150 GitHub employees signed an open letter re-stating their opposition to the contract, and denouncing alleged human rights abuses by ICE. As of November\u00a013, 2019,"}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " five workers had resigned over the contract."}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "The ICE contract dispute came into focus again in June 2020 due to the company's decision "}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": ", spurred by the George Floyd protests and "}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " movement."}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " Detractors of GitHub describe the branch renaming to be a form of "}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " and have urged GitHub to cancel their ICE contract instead."}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": " An open letter from members of the open source community was shared on GitHub in December 2019, demanding that the company drop its contract with ICE and provide more transparency into how they conduct business and partnerships. The letter has been signed by more than 700 people."}

{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "In 2023, parts of the social media platform "}

{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": ", the original developer of the Git software, has highly praised GitHub by stating \"The hosting of github ["}
{"title": ["GitHub"], "image": [], "desc": "] is excellent. They've done a good job on that. I think GitHub should be commended enormously for making open source project hosting so easy.\" However, he also sharply criticized the implementation of GitHub's merging interface, stating that \"Git comes with a nice pull-request generation module, but GitHub instead decided to replace it with their own totally inferior version. As a result, I consider GitHub useless for these kinds of things. It's fine for hosting, but the pull requests and the online commit editing, are just pure garbage.\""}

{"title": ["Git"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Git-logo.svg/150px-Git-logo.svg.png"], "desc": "Torvalds wanted a distributed system that he could use like BitKeeper, but none of the available free systems met his needs. He cited an example of a source-control management system needing 30 seconds to apply a patch and update all associated metadata, and noted that this would not scale to the needs of Linux kernel development, where synchronizing with fellow maintainers could require 250 such actions at once. For his design criterion, he specified that patching should take no more than three seconds, and added three more goals:"}
{"title": ["Git"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Git-logo.svg/150px-Git-logo.svg.png"], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["Git"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Git-logo.svg/150px-Git-logo.svg.png"], "desc": "These criteria eliminated every version-control system in use at the time, so immediately after the 2.6.12-rc2 Linux kernel development release, Torvalds set out to write his own."}
{"title": ["Git"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Git-logo.svg/150px-Git-logo.svg.png"], "desc": "\n"}

{"title": ["Git"], "image": ["//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Git-logo.svg/150px-Git-logo.svg.png"], "desc": " The first merge of multiple branches took place on 18 April."}

{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "YouTube began as a "}

{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " The site launched officially on December 15, 2005, by which time the site was receiving 8\u00a0million views a day."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " Clips at the time were limited to 100 megabytes, as little as 30 seconds of footage."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "YouTube was not the first video-sharing site on the Internet; "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " was launched in November 2004, though that site remained a side project of its developers from "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " The week of YouTube's launch, NBCUniversal "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " ran a skit \""}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "\" by "}

{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": ", \"Lazy Sunday\"'s status as an early "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " helped establish YouTube as an important website."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " Unofficial uploads of the skit to YouTube drew in more than five million collective views by February 2006 before they were removed when "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " requested it two months later based on copyright concerns."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " Despite eventually being taken down, these duplicate uploads of the skit helped popularize YouTube's reach and led to the upload of more third-party content."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " The site grew rapidly; in July 2006, the company announced that more than 65,000 new videos were being uploaded every day and that the site was receiving 100\u00a0million video views per day."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "The choice of the name "}

{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": ". That site's owner, "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": ", filed a lawsuit against YouTube in November 2006, after being regularly overloaded by people looking for YouTube. Universal Tube subsequently changed its website to "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "On October 9, 2006, "}

{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " The deal was finalized on November 13, 2006."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " Google's acquisition launched newfound interest in video-sharing sites; "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": ", which now owned Vimeo, focused on supporting the content creators to distinguish itself from YouTube."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " It is at this time YouTube issued the slogan \"Broadcast Yourself.\"\nThe company experienced rapid growth. "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " wrote that in 2007, YouTube consumed as much "}

{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " However, most of these views came from a relatively small number of videos; according to a software engineer at that time, 30% of videos accounted for 99% of views on the site."}

{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "Through this period, YouTube tried several new ways to generate revenue beyond advertisements. In 2013, YouTube launched a pilot program for content providers to offer premium, subscription-based channels."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " This effort was discontinued in January 2018 and relaunched in June, with US$4.99 channel subscriptions."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " These channel subscriptions complemented the existing Super Chat ability, launched in 2017, which allows viewers to donate between $1 and $500 to have their comment highlighted."}

{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " service."}

YouTube also released "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": ", a third app oriented towards streaming and discovering the music content hosted on the YouTube platform."}

{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "By February 2017, one billion hours of YouTube videos were being watched every day, and 400 hours worth of videos were uploaded every minute."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " Two years later, the uploads had risen to more than 500 hours per minute."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " During the "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": ", when most of the world was under "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": ", usage of services like YouTube significantly increased. One data firm"}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " estimated that YouTube was accounting for 15% of all "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": ", twice its pre-pandemic level."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " In response to EU officials requesting that such services reduce bandwidth as to make sure medical entities had sufficient bandwidth to share information, YouTube and "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " said they would reduce streaming quality for at least thirty days as to cut bandwidth use of their services by 25% to comply with the EU's request."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " YouTube later announced that they would continue with this move worldwide: \"We continue to work closely with governments and network operators around the globe to do our part to minimize stress on the system during this unprecedented situation.\""}

{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "After testing earlier in 2021, YouTube removed public display of dislike counts on videos in November 2021, claiming the reason for the removal was, based on its internal research, that users often used the dislike feature as a form of "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " and "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " While some users praised the move as a way to discourage "}

{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " referred to the update as \"a stupid idea\", and that the real reason behind the change was \"not a good one, and not one that will be publicly disclosed.\" He felt that users' ability on a social platform to identify harmful content was essential, saying, \"The process works, and there's a name for it: the "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": ". The process breaks when the platform interferes with it. Then, the platform invariably declines.\""}

{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "In 2022, YouTube launched an experiment where the company would show users who watched longer videos on TVs a long chain of short unskippable adverts, intending to consolidate all ads into the beginning of a video. Following public outrage over the unprecedented amount of unskippable ads, YouTube \"ended\" the experiment on September 19 of that year."}

{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "YouTube offers different features based on user verification, such as standard or basic features like uploading videos, creating playlists, and using "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": ", with limits based on daily activity (verification via phone number or channel history increases feature availability and daily usage limits); intermediate or additional features like longer videos (over 15 minutes), live streaming, custom thumbnails, and creating podcasts; advanced features like content ID appeals, embedding live streams, applying for monetization, clickable links, adding chapters, and pinning comments on videos or posts."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "In January 2012, it was estimated that visitors to YouTube spent an average of 15 minutes a day on the site, in contrast to the four or five hours a day spent by a typical US citizen watching television."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " In 2017, viewers on average watched YouTube on mobile devices for more than an hour every day."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "In December 2012, two billion views were removed from the view counts of Universal and "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " music videos on YouTube, prompting a claim by "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " that the views had been deleted due to a violation of the site's terms of service, which ban the use of automated processes to inflate view counts. That was disputed by "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": ", which said that the two billion views had been moved to Vevo, since the videos were no longer active on YouTube."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " On August 5, 2015, YouTube patched the formerly notorious behavior which caused a video's view count to freeze at \"301\" (later \"301+\") until the actual count was verified to prevent "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " YouTube view counts once again updated in real time."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " Since September 2019, subscriber counts are abbreviated. Only three leading digits of channels' subscriber counts are indicated publicly, compromising the function of third-party real-time indicators such as that of "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": ". Exact counts remain available to channel operators inside YouTube Studio."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "On November 11, 2021, after testing out this change in March of the same year, YouTube announced it would start hiding dislike counts on videos, making them invisible to viewers. The company stated the decision was in response to experiments which confirmed that smaller YouTube creators were more likely to be targeted in dislike "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " and harassment. Creators will still be able to see the number of likes and dislikes in the YouTube Studio dashboard tool, according to YouTube."}

{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "YouTube has faced numerous challenges and criticisms in its attempts to deal with copyright, including the site's first viral video, "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": ", which had to be taken down, due to copyright concerns."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " At the time of uploading a video, YouTube users are shown a message asking them not to violate copyright laws."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " Despite this advice, many unauthorized clips of copyrighted material remain on YouTube. YouTube does not view videos before they are posted online, and it is left to copyright holders to issue a "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " pursuant to the terms of the "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": ". Any successful complaint about copyright infringement results in a "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": ". Three successful complaints for "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " against a user account will result in the account and all of its uploaded videos being deleted."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " From 2007 to 2009 organizations including "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": ", "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": ", and the English "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " have filed lawsuits against YouTube, claiming that it has done too little to prevent the uploading of copyrighted material."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "In August 2008, a US court ruled in "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " that copyright holders cannot order the removal of an online file without first determining whether the posting reflected "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " of the material."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " YouTube's owner Google announced in November 2015 that they would help cover the legal cost in select cases where they believe fair use defenses apply."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "In the 2011 case of "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": ", professional singer Matt Smith sued Summit Entertainment for the wrongful use of copyright takedown notices on YouTube."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " He asserted seven "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": ", and four were ruled in Smith's favor."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " In April 2012, a court in Hamburg ruled that YouTube could be held responsible for copyrighted material posted by its users."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " On November 1, 2016, the dispute with GEMA was resolved, with Google content ID being used to allow advertisements to be added to videos with content protected by GEMA."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "In April 2013, it was reported that "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " and YouTube have a contractual agreement that prevents content blocked on YouTube by a request from UMG from being restored, even if the uploader of the video files a DMCA counter-notice."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " As part of YouTube Music, Universal and YouTube signed an agreement in 2017, which was followed by separate agreements other major labels, which gave the company the right to advertising revenue when its music was played on YouTube."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " By 2019, creators were having videos taken down or demonetized when Content ID identified even short segments of copyrighted music within a much longer video, with different levels of enforcement depending on the record label."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " Experts noted that some of these clips said qualified for fair use."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "In June 2007, YouTube began trials of a system for automatic detection of uploaded videos that infringe copyright. Google CEO Eric Schmidt regarded this system as necessary for resolving lawsuits such as the one from "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": ", which alleged that YouTube profited from content that it did not have the right to distribute."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " The system, which was initially called \"Video Identification\""}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " and later became known as Content ID,"}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " creates an ID File for copyrighted audio and video material, and stores it in a database. When a video is uploaded, it is checked against the database, and flags the video as a copyright violation if a match is found."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " When this occurs, the content owner has the choice of blocking the video to make it unviewable, tracking the viewing statistics of the video, or adding advertisements to the video.\n"}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "An independent test in 2009 uploaded multiple versions of the same song to YouTube and concluded that while the system was \"surprisingly resilient\" in finding copyright violations in the audio tracks of videos, it was not infallible."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " The use of Content ID to remove material automatically has led to "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " in some cases, as the videos have not been checked by a human for fair use."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " If a YouTube user disagrees with a decision by Content ID, it is possible to fill in a form disputing the decision."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "Before 2016, videos were not monetized until the dispute was resolved. Since April 2016, videos continue to be monetized while the dispute is in progress, and the money goes to whoever won the dispute."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " Should the uploader want to monetize the video again, they may remove the disputed audio in the \"Video Manager\"."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " YouTube has cited the effectiveness of Content ID as one of the reasons why the site's rules were modified in December 2010 to allow some users to upload videos of unlimited length."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "In 2021, two accounts linked to "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": ", the German channel of the Russian state-owned "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " network, were removed for breaching YouTube's policies relating to COVID-19."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " Russia threatened to ban YouTube after the platform deleted two German RT channels in September 2021."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " Shortly after the "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " in 2022, YouTube removed all channels funded by the Russian state."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " YouTube expanded the removal of Russian content from its site to include channels described as 'pro-Russian'. In June 2022, the "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " channel run by Russian military blogger and journalist "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " was deleted."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "In July 2023, YouTube removed the channel of British journalist "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": ", active in covering the "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " from 2014."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " In August 2023, a Moscow court fined Google 3\u00a0million rubles, around $35,000, for not deleting what it said was \"fake news about the war in Ukraine\"."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "In October 2024, a Russian court fined Google 2\u00a0undecillion "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " (equivalent to US$20"}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "decillion) for restricting Russian state media channels on YouTube."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " The fine imposed by Russia is far greater than the world's total GDP, estimated at US$110"}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "trillion by the "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " State news agency "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " reported that Google is allowed to return to the Russian market only if it complies with the court's decision."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " Kremlin spokesperson "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " labeled the court decision as \"symbolic\" and warned Google that it \"should not be restricting the actions of our broadcasters on its platform.\""}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "YouTube featured an "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " prank on the site on April 1 of every year from 2008 to 2016. In 2008, all links to videos on the main page were redirected to "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "'s music video \""}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "\", a prank known as \""}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "\"."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " The next year, when clicking on a video on the main page, the whole page turned upside down, which YouTube claimed was a \"new layout\"."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " In 2010, YouTube temporarily released a \"TEXTp\" mode which rendered video imagery into "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " letters \"in order to reduce bandwidth costs by $1 per second.\""}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "The next year, the site celebrated its \"100th anniversary\" with a range of sepia-toned silent, early 1900s-style films, including a parody of "}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "."}

{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": " service that offers movies and television shows for purchase or rental, depending on availability, along with a selection of movies (encompassing between 100 and 500 titles overall) that are free to stream, with interspersed ad breaks. YouTube began offering free-to-view movie titles to its users in November 2018; selections of new movies are added and others removed, unannounced each month."}

{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": ". In some countries, YouTube is blocked for more limited periods of time such as during periods of unrest, the run-up to an election, or in response to upcoming political anniversaries. In cases where the entire site is banned due to one particular video, YouTube will often agree to remove or limit access to that video in order to restore service."}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "\n"}
{"title": ["YouTube"], "image": [], "desc": "Reports emerged that since October 2019, comments posted with Chinese characters insulting the "}
